description:
'''Post-rock''' is a [[subgenre]] of [[experimental rock]] that emphasizes [[Texture (music)|texture]], atmosphere, and non-traditional song structures over conventional rock techniques. Post-rock artists often combine rock instrumentation and rock stylings with [[Electronic musical instrument|electronics]] and digital production as a means of enabling the exploration of textures, timbres and different styles. Vocals, when present, are often used as an instrumental layer, with many bands opting for entirely instrumental compositions. The genre began in [[Indie music scene|indie]] and [[underground music]] scenes, but deviated.

The term ''post-rock'' was coined by music journalist [[Simon Reynolds]] and popularized in his review of [[Bark Psychosis]]' 1994 album ''[[Hex (Bark Psychosis album)|Hex]]''. He later expanded the concept as music "using rock instrumentation for non-rock purposes". The term has since developed to refer to bands oriented around dramatic and suspense-driven [[instrumental rock]], making the term controversial among listeners and artists alike.

Groups such as [[Talk Talk]] and [[Slint]] are credited with producing foundational works in the style in the late 1980s and early 1990s. The release of [[Tortoise (band)|Tortoise]]'s 1996 album ''[[Millions Now Living Will Never Die]]'' led to post-rock becoming an established term for the genre in music criticism and journalism. In its second wave, post-rock diversified into subgenres, influencing indie rock, [[electronica]], and certain forms of metal.
